question:
(a) Write explanatory notes on the
(i) Equinoxes
(ii) Great circles

(b) Explain why the period of twilight is longer along the Arctic Circle than at the Equator
answer:
(a) (i) Equinoxes: Refers to two particular days of the year when all parts of the world will experience equal days and nights. These two days are March 21st and September 23rd. During these two days, the sun is vertically overhead at the equator and all parts of the earth will experience equal days and equal nights.

(ii) Great Circles: Any circle which divides a globe into two equal parts (or hemispheres) is a great circle. Examples are the equator, Greenwich meridian, meridian 180°, meridians 10°E and 170°W. 50°E and 130°W. etc. are all great circles. The number of great circles is limitless. It can extend east to west, north to south and so on provided it divides the globe into hemispheres.

(b) The reason(s) why the period of twilight is longer along the Arctic circle than at the Equator; 
The brief period between sun set and complete darkness is called twilight. This is caused by the fact that during the period of twilight, the earth receives diffused or refracted light from the sun while it is still below the horizon. Since the sunrises and sets in a vertical path at the Equator, the period during which refracted light is received is short. But at the arctic circle, the sun rises and sets in an obligue path and the period of refracted light is longer. It is much longer still at the poles.

question:
(a) Distinguish between deflation and abrasion

(b) Using specific examples, describe one landform produced by each of the processes ill (a) above

(c) Give any two reasons why wind erosion is more active in arid than in humid regions
answer:
(a) The differences between deflation and abrasion are as follows;
Deflation involves the lifting and blowing away of loose materials from the ground. Such unconsolidated sands and pebbles may be carried in the air or rolled along the ground depending on the size while abrasion involves the sand blasting of rock surfaces by winds when they hurl sand particles against them. The effect of sand blasting results in rock surfaces being scratched, polished and worn away.

(b) One landform produced by deflation is the deflation hollows. Deflation results in the lowering of the land surface gradually until large depressions are formed called deflation hollows. One landform produced by abrasion is the Rock pedestals. The sand blasting effect of winds against any projecting rock masses wears back the soft layers so that an irregular edge is formed on the alternate bands of hard and soft rocks. Grooves and hollows are cut in the rock surfaces, carving them into fantastic pillars called rock pedestals.

(c) Two reasons why wind erosion is more active in arid than in humid regions.

(i) In arid regions like the desert, wind erosion is more active because of absence of vegetation. Absence of vegetation enables the-wind to move at high speed thereby causing wind erosion.

(ii) Absence of moisture to bind the soil particles together. Since there is no moisture, the soil particles are loosely held hence they can easily be carried away by winds.

question:
Choose any two of the following vegetation types

(a) Equatorial

(b) Tropical continental

(c) Tropical desert and for each
(i) describe the vegetation characteristics
(ii) Explain how the vegetation has been influenced by climate
answer:
Two of the vegetation types are;
(a) Equatorial
(b) Tropical desert

(i) Characteristics of Equatorial vegetation are:

(i) The trees are evergreen due to absence of dry season.

(ii) The trees are mainly tall and broad leafed

(iii) The trees are mainly tropical hardwood

(iv) Trees are heterogeneous (different species)

(v) There are three distinct layers of the forest upper, middle and lower storeys

(vi) Lots of undergrowth e.g climbers, epiphytes, ropes, etc

(ii) The climatic conditions which influence the vegetation are:

(i) Great uniformity of temperatures throughout the year

(ii) The annual range of temperature is not more than 30°C

(iii) High mean monthly temperature, which is always around 26°C

(iv) Very heavy rainfall of 150 — 200cm, per annum which is well distributed.

(i) Characteristics of tropical desert are:

(i) Presence of combination of plants — grass, shrubs, herbs, roots etc.

(ii) Presence of xerophytes (drought resistant shrubs) e.g bulbous cacti

(iii) Presence of halophytes (salt loving plants)

(iv) Plants possess long roots with little or no leaves

(v) some possess thick succulent stems.

(vi) some shed their leaves during dry season

(ii) How the vegetation is influenced by climate; 

(i) Temperature is very high (30°C - 58°C)

(ii) Mean annual temperature is 32°C

(iii) Annual range of temperature is 9°C.

(iv) Rainfall is very low (25cm per annum)

question:
Select either urban flooding or water pollution and discuss its

(a) causes

(b) effects

(c) control measures
answer:
(a) Causes of urban flooding:

(i) Abundant supply of water from rainfall or ice

(ii) High water table which ensures a steady water supply

(iii) Weak dam construction and embarkments

(iv) Poor drainage system

(v) Blocking of drainage systems e.g gutters

(vi) Unplanned urban settlements

(b) Effects of urban flooding:

(i) Human lives are lost during urban flooding

(ii) Properties are damaged

(iii) Some roads may be washed away or rendered impassable

(iv) Some houses are completely taken over by water during flooding

(v) Deposits of garbage left behind by flood can cause environmental pollution.

(c) Control measure of urban flooding:

(i) Construction of strong embankments along the banks of rivers

(ii) Retardation of run off over the surface of water sheds

(iii) Storage of flood water behind dams to serve as flood control reservoirs

(iv) Stream channelization

(v) Legislation against indiscrimate dumping of refuse in gutters.

(vi).Construction of functional drainage systems.

question:
(a) Explain the term environmental resource

(b) Using specific examples, describe the importance of water as an environmental resource

(c) Outline any three sources of water.
answer:
(a) Environmental resource is any resource within our environment which is useful to man

(b) The importance of water as an environmental resource include the following:

(i) Rain water enables our crops to grow

(ii) Water from rivers can be used for construction of hydro-electric power supply (H. E. P)

(iii) Rainwater and water from rivers can be used for domestic and industrial uses

(iv) Rivers and seas provide employment for many people e.g fishermen

(v) Rivers, ponds, lakes, oceans provide food in form of protein to man e.g fish, shrimps crabs, etc

(vi) Rivers and ocean can be used for tourist centres

(c) Three sources of water:
(i) Rain water
(ii) Water from rivers
(iii) Water from the ground (ponds or wells)

question:
(a) Name any four functions of towns giving a specific example of each

(b) In what four ways can the initial function of a town contribute to its growth?

(c) Highlight any three ways in which rural settlements are dependent on urban settlements.
answer:
(a) Four functions of towns include:

(i) Industrial function

(ii) Commercial function

(iii) Administrative function

(iv) Residential function

(b) Four ways the initial function of a town contribute to its growth:

(i) As a result of the siting of many industries in a town due to large market, easy transportation, availability of power; people tend to migrate to the town to take up employment in the industries

(ii) Also, as a result of commercial activities in the town, people tend to settle in the town resulting in the growth of that town.

(iii) Due to the fact that the seat of government is located there, people tend to move closer to the government resulting in the growth of the town

(iv) The availability of social amenities such as pipe-borne water, electricity, etc, people tend to move into the town to enjoy these amenities resulting in its growth.

(c) Three ways in which rural settlements are dependent on urban settlements include:

(i) Urban settlements are usually the sources of manufactured goods for the rural settlements.

(ii) Urban settlements may also serve as administrative headquarters of the rural settlements

(iii) It is also a source of employment to rural settlements

question: In what ways can poor transportation limit the economic development of any one country?
answer:
Ways in which poor transportation can limit the economic development of a country e.g Niger Republic include:

(i) Poor transportation hinders easy movement of goods from one part of the country to another

(ii) It tends to reduce specialisation in production because there are no ways produce can easily move out or come into the country

(iii) Poor transportation lowers economic development because of lack of linkages of areas of production with consumption centres

(iv) It reduces trade between towns and countries

(v) It also lowers international integration and peace

(vi) Poor transportation hinders diffusion of ideas and innovations.

question:
(a) Account for the relative low level of industrial development in tropical Africa

(b) State five ways in which the industrial sector has contributed to the economic development of the region
answer:
(a) Reasons for the relatively low level of industrial development in tropical Africa are:

(i) Inadequate capital. Entrepreneurs in Africa do not have large capital to establish industries

(ii) Inadequate skilled manpower. There is serious shortage of skilled labour especially in management and technical staff

(iii) Small market The existence of small market (i.e consumers) prevents the growth of industries in Africa

(iv) Inadequate infrastructure -electricity, pipe borne water, telecommunication, roads, etc, are lacking hence a low growth of industries in Africa

(v) Shortage of raw-materials - Raw materials are not adequately available locally hence some depend on imported raw materials. This lowers industrial growth.

(b) Five contributions of industrial sector to the economic development of the region include:

(i) It leads to the diversification of economies

(ii) It has helped to conserve foreign exchange that would have been used in the importation of goods

(iii) Industrial sector provides employment to many people

(iv) It also raises the general standard of living of the people

(v) Industrial goods exported also generate foreign exchange to the country.

question:
(a) Discuss the relationship between rainfall and agricultural practices in the
(i) tropical continental region of Nigeria
(ii) sub-equatorial region of Nigeria

(b) In what five ways does agriculture contribute to the economy of Nigeria?
answer:
(a) (i) Rainfall has a lot of effects on agricultural activities in the tropical continental region of Nigeria in the following ways:

(i) Rainfall is low in this region

(ii) As a result of low rainfall, it gives rise to savanna type of vegetation

(iii) Agricultural activities in this area include the cultivation of cereal crops like maize, rice, millet sorghum, etc.

(iv) It also results in the rearing of cattle, sheep and cat due to abundance of grasses

(v) Low rainfall prevents the spread of tsetse flies thereby promoting the livestock activities

(ii)  on sub-equatorial region of Nigeria

(i) Rainfall is very high in the sub-equatorial region of Nigeria 

(ii) This high rainfall gives rise to rainforest type of vegetation

(iii) Agricultural activities in this re igo n involve the growth of tree crops like cocoa, kola, oil palm, rubber, etc

(iv) Due to lack of grasses, livestock is not popular.

(v) Timber is present hence people involve in lumbering activities.

(b) Five contributions of agriculture to the economy of Nigeria include:

(i) Provision of food for the people

(ii) It provides raw materials for industries

(iii) It provides employment to many people

(iv) It generates foreign exchange for the country

(v) It leads to the development of towns and villages

question:
(a) On an outline map of West Africa, mark and name the
(i) approximate position of the ITCZ in January;
(ii) low pressure belt in January;
(iii) high pressure belt in January;
(iv) position and direction of the Tropical Continental A, Mass in January;
(v) Guinea current;
(vi) Canary current

(b) Discuss the relationship between the pressure belts an rainfall distribution in West Africa.
answer: (b) There is direct relationship between pressure belts and rainfall distribution in Vest Africa. Pressure belts are created by temperature. When the temperature of a place is very high, it creates a high pressure belt. Wind which carries a lot of moisture therefore blows from a region of high pressure belt to regions of low pressure belts. This therefore results in heavy rainfall in areas of low pressure belts and light rainfall in areas of high pressure belts.

question:
(a) On an outline map of West Africa, mark and name the;
(i) Kossou dam; (ii) Kainji dam (iii) Akosombo dam, (iv) river on which each dam is located

(b) Highlight three ways in which climate affects dams in west Africa

(c) Stat three advantages and three disadvantages of dams to West Africa.
answer:
(b) Three ways in which climate affects dams in West Africa include:

(i) High rainfall increases the volume of water in the rivers while low rainfall lowers the amount of rainfall in rivers

(ii) High temperature tends to evaporate water from dams

(iii) Period of seasons, long dry season tends to reduce the volume of water in the rivers.

(c) Three advantages of dams to West Africa are:

(i) Generation of Hydro-Electric Power (H.E.P)

(ii) For irrigation purposes

(iii) It improves fishing and water navigation.

Three disadvantages of dams to West Africa are:

(i) Shortage of water in dam disrupts H.E.P output

(ii) It leads to low volume of water in rivers which hinders river navigation

(iii) Collapse of dams can result in urban flooding destroying properties and killing people.

(c) What can be done to minimize these problems?
answer:
(b) Four ways in which relief of Africa poses problems to the construction of trans-African highway from Cape of Good Hope to Cairo are:

(i) Presence of many highlands such as Kilimanjaro, Kenya highlands, etc.

(ii) Presence of many rivers which will demand high cost of constructing bridges across the rivers

(iii) Presence of deep valleys e.g Great East rift valley

(iv) Effects of wind erosion and deposition can disrupt the construction of such road.

(c) These problems can be minimized by;

(i) Construction of roads on fairly lowland areas

(ii)Avoiding presence of high mountains and valleys

(iii)Avoiding the presence of big rivers and planting trees along the roads in desert area.
